title: 103_hr199
content:
The "Commission on Retirement Income Policy Act of 1993" establishes a commission known as the Commission on Retirement Income Policy to carry out specific duties. The Commission on Retirement Income Policy Act of 1993 mandates a comprehensive review of retirement savings trends in the US, existing federal incentives, and the need for new programs to encourage and protect savings. The Commission will also address the funding sources for these programs and the most efficient ways to implement them. The Commission on Retirement Income Policy Act of 1993 mandates a review of retirement savings trends in the US, including the amounts needed for retirement income, workforce and demographic trends, the role of retirement savings in the economy, sources of retirement income, and the shift away from insured pension benefits. The Commission on Retirement Income Policy Act of 1993 mandates recommendations for future retirees, including pension plan coverage, adequate retirement income, benefit preservation, information on benefits, and dispute resolution procedures. The Commission on Retirement Income Policy Act of 1993 mandates recommendations for future retirees, including pension plan coverage, adequate retirement income, benefit preservation, information on benefits, and dispute resolution procedures. Additionally, any proposal for a new Federal incentive or program that would increase the Federal budget deficit must be accompanied by a recommendation for offsetting the increase in the report required under section 7. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 18 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and President pro tempore of the Senate within 90 days of the Act's enactment. Consultation with minority leaders is required for some appointments. The Commission consists of 18 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, and President pro tempore of the Senate. Members must be Members of Congress, business or labor leaders, academics, or individuals with distinctive qualifications. Each member serves for life, vacancies must be filled within 90 days, and members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. The Commission consists of 18 members appointed by various officials. 10 members constitute a quorum, with 6 able to hold hearings. The chairperson is elected by majority vote, meetings are called by the chairperson, and decisions require a majority vote of present members. SEC. 5. STAFF AND SUPPORT SERVICES. The Commission appoints an executive director and staff, sets their pay, and may hire additional personnel. The executive director and staff can be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. The Commission can also hire experts and consultants as needed. Upon request, federal agencies can provide staff support to the Commission. The Commission can request staff support from federal agencies on a reimbursable basis to assist in carrying out its duties under the Act. The Administrator of General Services can also provide administrative support services to the Commission as needed. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission under this Act has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, administer oaths, and receive evidence. Public hearings may also be conducted to gather public views on the private retirement system. Delegation of authority is allowed, and information can be obtained directly from federal agencies. The Commission under this Act can obtain information directly from federal agencies to carry out its responsibilities. It can also conduct public surveys and use the United States mails like other Federal agencies. The Commission under this Act has the authority to make purchases, contract for services, and accept gifts to assist its work. Gifts received will be deposited in the Treasury for disbursement as needed, and for tax purposes, they are considered gifts to the United States. The Commission under this Act can accept gifts, purchases, and services to support its work. Gifts accepted are considered gifts to the United States. The Commission may also use voluntary and uncompensated services as needed. SEC. 7. REPORT.

The Commission must submit a report by December 31, 1993, to the President, Senate leaders, and House leaders. The report will review required study matters and provide recommendations.

SEC. 8. TERMINATION.

The Commission will end within 90 days after submitting the report under section 7.
